title: SQL ServerPATINDEX()Function

metadata.description: Learn about SQL ServerPATINDEX()Function with clear explanations and practical examples.

content_sections.title: Details
content_sections.content:
❯
Example
Return the position of a pattern in a string:
SELECT PATINDEX('%schools%', '.com');

Definition and Usage
The PATINDEX() function returns the position of a pattern in a string.
If the pattern is not found, this function returns 0.
Note:
The search is case-insensitive and the first position in
string
is 1.
Syntax
PATINDEX(%
pattern
%,
string
)
Parameter Values
Parameter
Description
%
pattern
%
Required. The pattern to find. It MUST be surrounded by %. Other wildcards 
    can be used in
pattern
, such as:
% - Match any string of any length (including 0 length)
_ - Match one single character
[] - Match any characters in the brackets, e.g. [xyz]
[^] - Match any character not in the brackets, e.g. [^xyz]
string
Required. The string to be searched
Technical Details
Works in:
SQL Server (starting with 2008), Azure SQL Database, Azure SQL Data 
  Warehouse, Parallel Data Warehouse
More Examples
Example
Return the position of a pattern in a string:
SELECT 
  PATINDEX('%s%com%', '.com');

Example
Return the position of a pattern in a string:
SELECT PATINDEX('%[ol]%', '.com');

Example
Return the position of a pattern in a string:
SELECT PATINDEX('%[z]%', '.com');

❯
★
+1

options:

string
is 1
quiz.explanation: The correct definition of If the pattern is 'not found'.

quiz.question: What is The search?
options:
case-insensitive and the first position in
string
is 1
quiz.explanation:
The correct definition of The search is 'case-insensitive and the first position in
string
is 1'.

summary: This tutorial covers SQL ServerPATINDEX()Function concepts and techniques. You'll learn how to use SQL ServerPATINDEX()Function effectively, including key principles, common patterns, and practical examples. By the end of this tutorial, you'll have a solid understanding of SQL ServerPATINDEX()Function and how to apply it in your projects.
